title: Which presidential candidate will win Ohio?
preds: *This is definitely cheating - would work only in case GJO makes a mistake to include today in the scores (as indicated by resolution date)*
*This is definitely cheating - would work only in case GJO makes a mistake to include today in the scores (as indicated by resolution date)*
Donald Trump has won Ohio by a margin of 9 points.

I am going with Nate Silver on this. 
http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/ohio/
Updated based on early voting numbers, with turnout lower than expect, especially in highly Democratic Cayuga county.
Right now, based on polls and history, I show Trump right around a 52-53% chance of winning the votes which will count.

I'm sticking to 538. I can't do better than him I think:
http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/ohio/
Although the race is tight, RealClearPolitics has Trump up nearly 2 points in an average of polls. Trump is at 46.6%, while Clinton is at 45%.

NYT UPSHOT gives Trump has a 54% chance to win Ohio:
http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2016/upshot/ohio-election-forecast.html 538 gives Trump 67% chance of winning.  RCP poll average is now at 46.6 Trump, 45% Clinton The TargetSmart Ohio Early Vote survey:  
Clinton 48%, Trump 41%. I'm betting on the Beyonce effect. It's that even allowed here? lol
Also the high turn out of early votes from women in Ohio, if that same level of enthusiasm is kept for the election, I think the odds of Hillary winning increase.
According to the general news, 538.com, PredictIt.com, and GJP consensus.
The archetypal swing state, though polls suggest it will go for Trump. High white population should benefit Trump. Not an easy call though.

This Nov. 6 Columbus [Ohio] Dispatch article, http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/local/2016/11/06/dispatch-poll-finds-presidential-race-too-close-to-call.html#, says its a tie right now. I'm closing the gap between my probability estimates on Trump or Clinton winning my home state of Ohio.
Five thirty eight shows Trump's Ohio probability surging, but likely peaked at ~70% (http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/ohio/#plus). Expect a bit of settling into Nov 8.
Trump's lead in Ohio, though small, may be hard for clinton to overcome without extremely strong black turnout in cities. Most data on black turnout this year puts it below 2008 and 2012 levels.

Average of 5 Polls
Last Poll: Nov. 2
TRUMP 47%
Clinton 44%
DT has been consistently leading in the recent past.

Ohio has large pockets of rural voters who will support Donald Trump. Turnout among minorities is lower than expected which will reduce Secretary Clinton's pull in the urban areas. Senator Portman's strength will pull the state toward the Republicans.
HRC intent to reduce mining operations and low turnout of black vote.
The economic and trade message that Trump trumpets appears to be resonating strongly  with Ohio voters.

Trump has been gaining and leads in the recent polls. He is also on a pretty good streak of not drawing negative attention to himself, while meanwhile Clinton continues to face new negative news including the whole FBI email thing.

Trump has been ahead in almost all the polls. CNN also said the early voting results in Ohio so far was "bad news" for Clinton.  I started with Nate Silver's predictions and then factored in what I've seen in the news and polls to come up with these numbers.

Trump is aheadby 2 points in the RCP average, he's also ahead in Quinnipiac poll (Nov 1) by 3 points.  Clinton is leading in early voting. She also Reuters/Ipsos ahead by 4 pts in the Reuters/Ipsos polls released this week. Undecided and GOTV might decide Ohio. Giving Hillary the lead given early voting numbers.
It's too close to call.  The state has a high proportion of Trump's core demographic, i.e. less educated white folks.
In Florida, North Carolina and Ohio, which allow early voting, Clinton has large leads. In Florida, she leads by six percentage points among early voters. (Politico.com)

Polling changes daily. Donnie could squeak by in Buckeye State but winning "Electoral College" is another question. Link here http://www.dailywire.com/news/5361/can-trump-beat-hillary-here-are-latest-polls-james-barrett#

This Nov. 1 Washington Post article, https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2016/11/01/donald-trump-now-leads-in-two-of-his-three-must-win-states-but-the-path-forward-is-grim/, notes that Trump has gained in my home state of Ohio. It was already tied, and momentum for Trump, and enthusiasm dip for Clinton could tip it Trump's way. I'm increasing my probability estimate slightly that Trump can win Ohio.
polls have shifted in favor of trump. Wasn't keeping up on this one.
According to the general news, 538.com, PredictIt.com, and GJP consensus.
+4 DT, email saga 2.0 will get more Reps to polls despite DT.  http://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-37805525

This Oct. 27 article on Cleveland.com,  http://www.cleveland.com/politics/index.ssf/2016/10/early_vote_numbers_in_ohio_sug.html, notes that request for absentee ballots for Dem-leaning voters is down significantly in Ohio (compared to Obama elections) and up in Repub-leaning areas of the state. As many have noted, turnout may be a key factor. I'm raising my probability estimate significantly that Trump could win my home state of Ohio.
44 polls listed with margin of error; probability of leading averaged.

Latest polls show Trump could win in Ohio. I live in the state and am surrounded by Trump signs. A recent drive through various parts of the state showed Trump signs out number Clinton signs at least five to one. There are also signs which are becoming more prevalent that state "Lock Up Hillary." The rural areas will vote for Trump, the metro area for Clinton.

Suffolk univ. 
TRUMP 44,8%
Clinton 44,6%
* The poll was conducted October 17 to 19, outside of the third presidential debate in part.
According to the general news, 538.com, PredictIt.com, and GJP consensus.
Expecting another mid-Aug to mid-Sep 'esque tightening (Trump upswing), projecting to an Ohio win probability in the lower 50s. Fortunately for Clinton, Florida's swing will likely decide the race.
Downing my prediction to a 50%/50% "Even" it's going to be a "Nip & Tuck" race to the wire.
Dropping the odds HRC wins Ohio on what looks like a smaller than expected post hot-mic bounce.

This Oct. 20 Columbus Dispatch article, http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/local/2016/10/20/ohio-politics-now-donald-trump-delaware-debate.html, might provide some insight about the current state of the race in my home state of Ohio. Tied before the debate, it seems some elements during the debate may tip the scales for Clinton in Ohio.  I'm slightly raising my probability estimate Clinton will win Ohio.

Most recent polls:  Tie with Trump leading by 2 pts on some  http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/president/oh/ohio_trump_vs_clinton-5634.html Clinton's campaign in that state is so aggressive I will err on her side on this one. Will keep an eye on the polls. For reference, Ohio is the second-highest state for ad spending in this presidential race. (Florida is the first, with $37.7 million from Clinton and $9.2 million from Trump)    
Clinton and groups supporting her campaign have spent, as of the end of September, $26.6 million on media in Ohio.  Trump and his allies had spent $7.1 million.  Source:  Cook Political Report. 
http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/local/2016/09/27/donald-trump-tries-to-appeal-to-midwest-with-trade-talk-at-debate.html
A RealClearPolitics average of state polls gives Clinton a five-point lead over Trump. And a Baldwin Wallace University poll conducted from Oct. 9-11 puts her nine points ahead

This Oct. 15 NBC News article,  http://www.nbcnews.com/politics/2016-election/trump-s-ohio-campaign-director-severs-ties-state-gop-chairman-n666916, reports on the split announced today between the Trump campaign and the Ohio state Repub chairman. This could very well hurt Trump in my home state of Ohio. I'm raising my probability estimate Clinton will win Ohio.
Latest poll showing 1 point lead for Trump, who is likely underestimated in polls.

This Oct. 12 Cleveland.com article, http://www.cleveland.com/open/index.ssf/2016/10/new_ohio_poll_puts_hillary_cli.html, indicates Clinton has taken the lead in Ohio due to recent current events. I'm increasing my probability estimate Clinton will win Ohio.

I actually think HRC is getting stronger, but Ohio may be a hold-out bastion, so playing GJO odds and dialing back prior percentages to give space for a DT win. (My prior numbers for an HRC win were higher.....again, just playing a n insurance bet.)

Mr Trump's messages about urban decay and globalization ring especially true in Ohio.  While recent polling has showed Secy. Clinton ahead, her lead is tenuous at best, and Mr. Trump is likely at his lowest point.  I predict a slight bounce from the second debate and more as people digest the contents of wikileaks emails.

Overall shift for Clinton, it should reflect in Ohio. 27 days to come.
I must confess, i am thinking that i am very conservative.

Slight adjustment since Trump is losing more party support over the weekend. But the polls are still tight and I imagine the most recent ones are probably a bit skewed towards Hillary from a bounce from the Access Hollywood video news.

This Oct. 5 Politico article, http://www.politico.com/blogs/swing-states-2016-election/2016/10/poll-who-is-winning-in-ohio-229188, explains that Clinton had a tiny lead in my home state of Ohio. But that was before the Access Hollywood tape and second debate. Most likely Clinton's lead in Ohio has expanded during the last 72 hours. I'm increasing my probability estimate Clinton will win Ohio.

http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/ohio/
http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/president/oh/ohio_trump_vs_clinton_vs_johnson_vs_stein-5970.html Ohio	Early voting starts 35 days before Election Day
Fine tuning the projected "hot mic" impact and the increased expectation that another surprise could hit before November
http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/ohio/#plus Swing back towards Clinton since the first debate and Trump's leaked video.
According to the general news, 538.com, PredictIt.com, and GJP consensus.
Update is based on latest set of polls.  This is subject to change (of course) based on the second presidential debate.

Changing my forecast due to this weekend's big news - which led to Rob Portman & many other Republicans dropping their endorsements. Also, some polling before the news broke reflected better odds of a Clinton victory. Tonight's townhall style debate could be Hillary's knockout punch.
Portman (R) who will whup Strickland in senate race, has withdrawn support for Trump. Link http://www.cleveland.com/open/index.ssf/2016/10/rob_portman_rescinds_endorseme.html#incart_2box

Clinton 48% 
Trump 47% 10/5/2016 Anzalone Liszt Grove poll

Ohio is full of undecideds traditionally.  But the recent poll (since debate) has Hillary up, but only by a little. I am going to be a bit more conservative with my estimate.

Clinton has gained ground in Ohia and could win beyond "margin of error."  Link to lots of "scientific polls" here
http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/latest_polls/president/
Getting a lot closer according to 5-30-8

In this Oct. 3 CNN article, http://www.cnn.com/2016/10/03/politics/hillary-clinton-donald-trump-swing-state-presidential-polling/, the battle in Ohio is explored. Trump is ahead in recent polls of Ohio voters. I'm slightly increasing my probability estimate Trump could win Ohio.
DT holding the lead in the polls.  Seems the state polls, other than in Ohio, are moving toward HRC.
According to the general news, 538.com, PredictIt.com, and GJP consensus.
Trend in Real Clear Polls is in HRC's favor.  Portman may not be enough to win it for DT.

+1 Clinton

538:
''Still, the polls have told a pretty consistent story overall. Among the 11 swing state polls conducted since the debate, Clinton has led in all 11''
http://fivethirtyeight.com/features/election-update-clintons-debate-performance-is-helping-her-in-swing-states/

I just came down a lot yesterday to be closer to consensus, but it looks like the Clinton camp just isn't too concerned with Ohio.  From the NY Times: Ohio, Long a Bellwether, Is Fading on the Electoral Map
By JONATHAN MARTINSEPT. 29, 2016 ATHENS, Ohio- After decades as one of America’s most reliable political bellwethers, an inevitable presidential battleground that closely mirrored the mood and makeup of the country, Ohio is suddenly fading in importance this year. Hillary Clinton has not been to the state since Labor Day, and her aides said Thursday that she would not be back until next week, after a monthlong absence, effectively acknowledging how difficult they think it will be to defeat Donald J. Trump here... But its Rust Belt profile, Mr. Trump’s unyielding anti-trade campaign and Mrs. Clinton’s difficulty energizing Ohio’s young voters have made it a lesser focus for Democrats this year, even as it remains critical to Mr. Trump’s path to the White House... And with a once-competitive Senate race in Ohio turning into a rout for Rob Portman, the Republican incumbent, Democrats can quietly pull back from the state with little fear of down-ballot consequences... http://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/30/us/politics/ohio-campaign-trump-clinton.html?hp&action=click&pgtype=Homepage&clickSource=story-heading&module=first-column-region&region=top-news&WT.nav=top-news&_r=2
Polls have been volatile and vote looks close. Next two debates will influence further changes in my prediction.
Updating my forecast - HRC down to 40% from 55% - due to 538's forecast model showing these exact numbers. Will look to update after the debate.
According to the general news, 538.com, PredictIt.com, and GJP consensus.

Recent polls have Hair Boy narrowly winning Ohio.  This is more likely to get D's and I's out to vote for Hillary, one suspects.  She'll win it, but it will be close.   On the larger front, she can lose Ohio and Florida and still go back to live in the White House, which her husband described as "the world's best public housing."
Polls are shifting in Trumps favor. Many recent ones have him up in Ohio.
Ohio seems to have settled on Trump ... not sure if the debate will change that

Now that is a much tighter and realistic margin, more confidence in this prediction now.

Now that Trump has backed out of revealing all his health details and Dr. Lisa Bardack has released her "fit to serve" opinion on HRC, chances of a new Democratic nominee are minimal. Trump can't attack HRC too hard as he is not on the strongest footing himself, and Bardack's note signals HRC's intention of not backing out. Dropping 'Someone else' to 2% from 10%. Will drop it to 0% after the first debate on Sep 26.

According to this Sept. 14, CNN article, Trump is now leading in Ohio: http://www.cnn.com/2016/09/14/politics/cnn-orc-poll-florida-ohio-donald-trump-hillary-clinton/. I'm flipping my probability estimate -- instead of Clinton, I'm giving Trump a better than even chance of winning my home state.

If HRC has Parkinson's or something similar, there is a reasonable chance she will have to quit the race before the TV debates, so that another Democrat candidate can run in her place. In such a situation, this question will go for a complete toss, since it mentions only DT and HRC, instead of the more robust categorization of Republicans vs. Democrats (like in the two Presidential questions).  Personally, I think HRC would rather die than step aside, and since the decision is completely up to her (as per DNC bylaws), the development is unlikely. So I can't give much more than 10% for this. Will give the probability  back to HRC once the debates start (Sep 26) without HRC stepping down.
http://www.wnd.com/2016/09/democrats-meeting-in-secret-to-pick-hillary-replacement/
http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2016/09/13/what-happens-if-clinton-drops-out.html Also, DT leads HRC in Ohio by 5% now. 70% probability makes sense for that kind of lead.
http://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2016-09-14/ohio-poll
Latest Ohia poll shows Trump is pulling ahead  here is link   http://www.cleveland.com/open/index.ssf/2016/09/donald_trump_extends_lead_over.html#incart_2box

Since the election appears to be closer than anticipated, it makes sense to back Trump to win at least some of the battleground states (especially since my overall forecast is for a Democrat victory).  Of the key states in play, I think Ohio is definitely more likely than Penn, and perhaps slightly more likely than Florida, to go with Trump.
According to the general news, 538.com, PredictIt.com, and GJP consensus.

This Sept. 9, Dayton Daily News article notes that Trump is slightly ahead in Ohio per recent poll, http://www.daytondailynews.com/news/news/trump-leads-clinton-in-ohio-poll-says/nsTRB/. I'm increasing my probability estimate Trump could win Ohio.
Everything indicates OH is a true toss up. Not sure where GJO is getting HRC as a 2 to 1.

According to this Sept. 3 Politico article, Trump trailing Clinton in Ohio (my home state) by 3.2 percentage points: http://www.politico.com/blogs/5-political-numbers-to-watch/2016/09/campaign-2016-week-numbers-227706. That's pretty close and the trend seems to be that the public's opinion of Clinton is getting worse. Of course, public opinion on Trump is also problematic for him. I'm lowering my probability estimate that Clinton will win Ohio, raising it that Trump could win the state.

Newest polls I've seen show the race getting close to even in Ohio. Meanwhile Trump has strung together a few weeks without any major negative headlines, while Clinton is facing further email and foundation questions.

Ohio is very blue in the North (HRC in the primaries), very red in the South (but went for Ohio governor John Kasick in the primaries).   Could go either way, 3-2 odds for Clinton.

Not seeing any more polls with Trump tied as we get further from the conventions. Also, overall all I'm feeling more like Clinton will win, so some of my reasoning for that naturally filters down to the state contests.

Democrats won last 2 presidential elections in Ohio. Majority of polls show Mrs. Clinton lead. 
In this moment even Republican party stalwarts are turning against Mr. Trump.

A recent poll shows the two candidates tied. This Cincinnati TV station article provides some background: http://www.wcpo.com/news/insider/who-will-win-ohio-polls-show-a-dead-even-race-between-donald-trump-and-hillary-clinton As a result, I'm narrowing my forecasting spread between Clinton and Trump.

For all states that I am going to update, think the Hillary bounce is real.  But, I worry about more e-mail fallout.   Amazingly, team Clinton still hasn't gotten the email story right and in the rear view mirror.  Come on guys, say what needs to be said and get it over with.  Be honest but not stupid, say you learned from the experience, memorize your (lawyer and focus group approved) talking points.  You don't want to be explaining stuff in late October.   On the flip side, Trump isn't going to change.  Now that we are in the general election, the pressure will be worse, the out and out lies will continue (but now be fact checked), thin skin will be pricked, lack of organization will be a liability.  The Trump clown circus will remain in full show for the rest of the summer and fall.   I intend to move towards 538 odds tonight, half way between polls plus and polls only for all states.

My home state of Ohio could tip either way, but oddsmakers in political prediction give Clinton 3-1 odds overall, per CNN article here: http://www.cnn.com/2016/08/01/politics/hillary-clinton-donald-trump-odds-political-prediction-market/ I'm increasing my probability estimate Clinton will win Ohio.

I'm increasing my probability estimate Clinton will win Ohio. This is based on current momentum of both candidates:  Clinton up, Trump down. Endorsements for Clinton by Republicans and others, and lack of endorsements for Trump seem significant. Related CNN article: http://www.cnn.com/2016/08/01/politics/hillary-clinton-donald-trump-odds-political-prediction-market/

OK, we are now post conventions.  Trump has been trump, pulls have changed.  They should settle in a few weeks, but for now, going to 60% Hillary.  538 is around 53%, Upshot is 59%.  Waiting for more data.

PredictWise pick. According to DAL, it's a 50:50 tie. Curious to see whose prediction source is more accurate.
http://predictwise.com/politics/2016-president-winner
According to general news, gjp. and 538.com.
Facebook poll conducted by me. Very sorry about the outcome.

Kasich's snub of Trump will make a difference since Kasich is respected in my home state of Ohio. I'm not sure Ohioans will like a New York City guy like Trump. Right now, I give Clinton the edge. Here's article from Dayton, Ohio, newspaper: http://www.daytondailynews.com/news/news/national-govt-politics/with-conventions-over-race-shifts-to-ohio/nr7Gq/

- 2 from 51 Hillary Clinton Bounce from the convention and demographic data: «With 93% of its population being white the demographics aren't very representative of the US, but its per capita income of $28,703 (£21,896) is the US average almost to the dollar.»
 http://www.bbc.com/news/election-us-2016-36872456

Moving forward, beyond Kaine's teleprompter Spanglish, the clown car of bought and paid for Clintonite pundits,  and the megadata  vaccumed from "internet of feelings"  Ohio's governor Kasich will finally get active in the zone to help Donnie pull out the win just before race hits home stretch. He is more dynamic and  can reach across party lines beter than Kaine, who is awkward insider, and preaches to the choir as a former Democratic National Committee boss.  Pence will shape shift into a more aggyessive campaigner to avoid getting "Quayled" by Dem controlled anti-Trump media. Clinton camp made big tactical error by not choosing Vilsack as VP.  Also, recent "tweaking" of polls (favoring Hillary mostly) makes the pollsters a new target for "populists" of all stripes.  Ditto softening of "margin of error" to remove "error."  My intention is not to promote Trump here, but to note the general devolution of the campaign process. Ohio is still the ultimate swing state and Kasich (although a Steeler fan;) will play big in the red zone.  http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/local/2016/07/27/kasich-focused-on-ohio-not-national-politics-at-state-fair.html Kaine flip-flopper  http://www.redstate.com/brandon_morse/2016/07/29/tim-kaines-flip-flops-multiple-times-amendment-restricts-federal-abortion-spending/
Trump could pull this off dependent on turn out and registration of the white non college demographic, the same demographic that is influencing voter results in Europe
http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/ohio/#plus has Trump at 51%. This ties in with Portman's lead in the Senate race.

After seeing the market positioning of the two campaigns in their conventions, I think the Dems have the edge in getting swing states, and keeping marginally Dem states. The biggest risk to the forecast would be some current event that reinforces a darker world-view.
DT is a little to in your face for  a lot of Ohioans, but it's close.

I was wrong.   Polls are about a popularity contest in the summer of 2016.  The election is about a marketing campaign that is focusing on November 2016.  So, lets look at the two sides.  Trump has ... Trump. (And his kids, and Kasich).  It's a one (and a half) ring circus, with one star.  Hillary has ... Oh my god... Everyone.  Tonight I watched Bernie shift to become a strong backer of Hillary.  (Bernie, I have never been more impressed with you.)  (To me, Bernie's was the most important speech of the convention.)  Last week I watched Cruz scream fire in a crowded theater.  I watched Michelle talk about protection, education and mentors of our children, and trust in Hillary.  I watched Melania Trump give a stiff, but good speech, to find out some of it was plagiarized.  I watched Elizabeth Warren on message and effective.  I expedited an old actor to start talking to an empty chair.  My point is the Republicans were incompetent, self serving, and felt like an off script Apprentice, the Democrats were organized, enthusiastic, and (mostly) for Hillary.  Further, from what I see, Trump will be for ... wait for it ... Trump.  Bill Clinton, Michelle Obama, Barack Obama, Elizabeth Warren, Joe Biden, Bernie Sanders (I'm still proud) et. al. are at least making motions like they will help Hillary win.  And a lot of these folks will focus on a hand full of states.  Oh My God.  The other issue is organization.  From what I understand. Hillary has been creating infrastructure for over a year.  She has boots on the ground, ads in the schedule, and money in the bank.  Trump ... hopes the RNC can help him out.  Donors are contributing to Hillary, and until the last month, The Donald was using Twitter.  Trump thinks in 140 characters or less.  Don't get me wrong, the clown still gets lots of attention.  Interesting comparison. Changing my forecast at the state level at last for a few months to 1/2 the distance from the 538 blog to 90% Hillary.  Things to watch for is shock and awe by the Democrats, or the Circus is winning for the Republicans.  (Rounding to the nearest 5% towards 538 , i.e., lean to the mean).  One way or the other, the good old Brier score will be taught a lesson.
Much like Florida, it will be very close, but Hillary should win. The Republican Convention had little effect. Again, increasing percentages of minorities who are likely to vote is a big factor.
Clinton and Kaine will be painted as pro-trade in a state which has suffered job losses from globalization.

The feud between Kasich and Trump continues.  That may affect Trump's numbers but doesn't necessarily mean that Republicans will vote for Hillary.   These are the latest major polls showing Hillary leading or tied with Trump.  http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/president/oh/ohio_trump_vs_clinton-5634.html
The prediction market has a number of early predictions on the presidential race - including Ohio. http://predictwise.com/politics/2016-president-winner
Too close to call at this point.
Ohio's governor will endorse Trump as a fellow Republican party member, The Republican National convention will also bring up support for their party.

giving HRC a slight edge based on difficult suburbs for Trump according to this article: http://www.wsj.com/articles/donald-trump-faces-challenge-surpassing-mitt-romney-in-ohio-1469059702?

This one could be close. HRC seems to be consistently up in recent polling, though not by much. There are some interesting wild cards that could influence the result in Ohio. I'm really curious to see how involved Kasich will be in the campaign. Usually having a party-affiliated governor would be a positive for a nominee, but... well, Trump. It'll also be interesting to see if Clinton opts for Sherrod Brown as her veep. If she does, that'd give her a handy bump here. We'll see.
